Card_1.description: You’re heading for an important conference over the weekend, and your hair needs some grooming and styling.

Card_2.description: It is perfectly alright to use your credit card for discretionary expenses like haircare - but ensure that you can pay off these expenses in full at the time your credit card bill is due. Otherwise, a $50 haircut can cost you much more than that simply in late fees, interest, and penalties.

Card_3.description: Your dog is ill. The vet charges a bomb but you can’t see your dog suffer!

Card_4.description: Credit Cards can be very useful in times of emergency, especially if you don't have the funds on hand immediately. But remember, you must be able to pay off the entire credit card bill (including such emergency expenses) when it becomes due. An emergency fund will help in such cases.

Card_5.description: Your grandmother isn’t keeping well. You want to go visit her in the village but tickets are expensive at this time of the year.

Card_6.description: The credit card limit is the maximum you can spend using the credit card, without paying off at least a little. However, that doesn't mean that you should spend till the limit is exhausted. The credit utilization ratio is the amount you spend as compared to your credit limit. For example, if you spend $100 and you credit card limit is $500, your credit utilization ratio is 20%. The lower you are able to maintain this ratio, the better.

Card_7.description: You’ve received a $50 tax refund! Coincidentally there is a new sushi place you really wanted to try.

Card_8.description: You discover $150 in an old piggy bank. You can pay off some credit card debt or leave the money as it is.

Card_9.description: A good way to maintain a low credit utilization ratio, even if you do end up spending a bit more than anticipated, is to pay it off as and when you have some extra money. You need not even wait for the bill due date!

Card_10.description: Uh-oh. The car has broken down and the repair will cost $50. You can use the vacation fund to pay it off, or put it on your credit card.

Card_11.description: Sometimes it is easier to buy things using your credit card, than to buy them using the money you have put aside for other purposes. However, keep in mind that if you are unable to pay the credit card bill in its entirety when it is due, it will cost you a lot more in fees, interest, and penalties!

Card_12.description: You bought $100 tickets to your favorite band’s concert. But the cab there will take another $50.

Card_13.description: You need to buy a birthday gift for your neighbour’s son. You have a choice of buying a single toy car or a set of two, one of which you can gift to someone else later.

Card_14.description: Your office is hosting a weekend getaway for all the staff, which will cost each person $100. You have some money set aside for the down payment for your house. Do you use that or put it on your card?

Card_15.description: Goal-based saving is an excellent technique to put aside money for the bigger expenses in life. We find it easier to cut back expenses in the present if we are able to link that to something that is achievable in the future. But be careful that you prioritize your goals carefully. Taking on debt in the present while simultaneously saving for the future, is not the wisest decision and will cost you more in the long run.

Card_16.description: One of your friends gifted you tickets to the latest musical at the theatre. On reaching there, you realize you’ve lost the tickets.

Card_17.description: You need to buy fuel for your car. You will get a discount if you pay via the credit card.

Card_18.description: A great advantage of using credit cards is the various discounts and other offers that come along with them. Being smart and strategic with the way you utilize these discounts can save you a lot of money! However, be sure to keep your utilization ratio low by mainly using your card for such discounted expenses.

Card_19.description: Your favourite niece is turning 3 and she has been adorably asking for a toy car she can ride around the garden; little does she care that it costs a neat $300!

Card_20.description: Your phone carrier offers you a phone upgrade to the newest model, right in time as your old phone starts to give out.

Card_21.description: Large and sudden expenses can be difficult to afford. Using a credit card for them can give you some breathing space to get the funds together. But remember, the larger the expense, the more you will have to pay in interest. The only way to avoid that is to pay off the entire expense before the bill becomes due!

Card_22.description: Uh-oh. Your trusted old oven has given way, and your kitchen cannot function without one.

Card_23.description: You’ve had your eye on an ergonomic chair for your home office since quite a while. You’re tired of sitting at your kitchen island for work calls. You can get the basic model or splurge on the top of the range one.

Card_24.description: You need to feed the parking meter while attending an office meeting downtown.

Card_25.description: You’ve won $100 concert tickets through a contest on the radio station, and it is on your birthday! You only need to pay postage to receive them, and you happen to have a few dollars saved up - but it was for your gym membership.

Card_26.description: Your new boss has invited you over for a friendly lunch at their place. You want to make a good first impression. Will you gift them a branded Crystal Memento or a Generic One?

Card_27.description: The thermostat is broken and, as they say, winter is coming. Although your landlord is supposed to repair it, you know they take their own sweet time.

Card_28.description: You’re getting mighty tired of chopping vegetables all weekend long, in your new quest to eat healthy home-made food. A new app lets your order pre-cut veggies, saving you the hassle.

Card_29.description: Yay! Holiday season is here, and you get to visit your family for an entire week. The only drawback - your dog needs to stay in doggy day care!

Card_30.description: A neighbourhood grandma has offered to do all your laundry for you, saving you close to 10 hours each month, to say nothing of the headache. She charges a bit, but is still cheaper than getting it done from a chain laundry.

Card_31.description: Your hometown has suffered tremendously in a recent natural calamity. You would want to contribute as much as you possibly can, but you’re not in the best position yourself.

Card_32.description: Oh no. Your trusted old car has finally broken down beyond repair. Your town doesn’t have the best public transport, and you need a car for work. Luckily, you found a great deal on a used car, but it needs a hefty down payment.

Card_33.description: Another reason to keep your credit utilisation ratio low is to keep your credit limit free for such large expenses. In this case, your credit card limit is $500. Only if you have completely paid off your previous bill, and not spent anything else using your credit card after that, would you be able to afford this $500 charge!
